Fixation}}

'Fixation' is a concept originated by Sigmund Freud (1905a) to denote the
persistence of anachronistic sexual traits'. Salman Akhtar, Comprehensive
Dictionary of Psychoanalysis (London 2009) p. 112 Subsequently '"Fixation"
acquired a broader connotation. With the development of theory of libidinal
stages...the term came to mean a persistent attachment, not only to the specific
instinctual aims of a particular era, but, instead, to the entire complex of
self and object relation' Akhtar, p. 112 at that time.

More generally, it is the state in which an individual becomes obsessed with an
attachment to another person, being or object (in human psychology): 'A strong
attachment to a person or thing, especially such an attachment formed in
childhood or infancy and manifested in immature or neurotic behavior that
persists throughout life'. [http://www.answers.com/topic/fixation
